THE WRIGHT'S CHASTE WIFE. [MS. Lambeth 306, fol. 178‚Äì187.] Allemyghty god, maker of alle, Saue you my souereyns in towre & halle, And send you good grace! If ye wylle a stounde blynne, Of a story I wylle begynne, And telle you alle the cas, Meny farleyes √æat I haue herde, Ye would haue wondyr how yt ferde; Lystyn, and ye schalle here; Of a wryght I wylle you telle That some tyme in thys land gan dwelle, And lyued by hys myster. Whether that he were yn or oute, Of erthely man hadde he no dowte, To werke hows, harowe, nor plowgh, Or other werkes, what so they were, Thous wrought he hem farre and nere, And dyd tham wele I-nough. Thys wryght would wedde no wyfe, Butt yn yougeth to lede hys lyfe In myrthe and o√ære melody; Ouer alle where he gan wende, Alle they seyd ‚Äúwelcome, frende, Sytt downe, and do gla[d]ly.‚Äù Tylle on a tyme he was wyllyng, As tyme comyth of alle thyng, (So seyth the profesye,) A wyfe for to wedde & haue That myght hys goodes kepe & saue, And for to leue alle foly. Ther dwellyd a wydowe in √æat contre That hadde a doughter feyre & fre; Of her, word sprang wyde, For sche was bothe stabylle & trewe, Meke of maners, and feyre of hewe; So seyd men in that tyde. The wryght seyde, ‚Äúso god me saue, Such a wyfe would I haue To lye nyghtly by my syde.‚Äù He √æought to speke wyth √æat may, And rose erly on a daye And √æyder gan he to ryde. The wryght was welcome to √æe wyfe, And her saluyd alle so blyve, And so he dyd her doughter fre: For the erand that he for came Tho he spake, √æat good yemane; Than to hym seyd sche: The wydow seyd, ‚Äúby heuen kyng, I may geue wyth her no √æing, (And √æat forthynketh me;) Saue a garlond I wylle the geue, Ye schalle neuer see, whyle ye lyve, None such in thys contre: Haue here thys garlond of roses ryche, In alle thys lond ys none yt lyche, For ytt wylle euer be newe, Wete √æou wele withowtyn fable, Alle the whyle thy wyfe ys stable The chaplett wolle hold hewe; And yf thy wyfe vse putry, Or tolle eny man to lye her by, Than wolle yt change hewe, And by the garlond √æou may see, Fekylle or fals yf √æat sche be, Or ellys yf sche be trewe.‚Äù Of thys chaplett hym was fulle fayne, And of hys wyfe, was nott to layne; He weddyd her fulle sone, And ladde her home wyth solempnite, And hyld her brydalle dayes thre. Whan they home come, Thys wryght in hys hart cast, If that he walkyd est or west As he was wonte to done, ‚ÄúMy wyfe √æat ys so bryght of ble Men wolle desyre here fro me, And √æat hastly and sone;‚Äù Butt sone he hym by√æought That a chambyr schuld be wrought Bothe of lyme and stone, Wyth wallys strong as eny stele, And dorres sotylly made and wele, He owte framyd yt sone; The chambyr he lett make fast, Wyth plaster of parys √æat wylle last, Such ous know I neuer none; Ther ys kyng ne emperoure, And he were lockyn in √æat towre, That cowde gete owte of √æat wonne. Nowe hath he done as he √æought, And in the myddes of the flore wrought A wondyr strange gyle, A trapdoure rounde abowte That no man myght come yn nor owte; It was made wyth a wyle, That who-so touchyd yt eny thyng, In to √æe pytt he schuld flyng Wythyn a lytylle whyle. For hys wyfe he made that place, That no man schuld beseke her of grace, Nor her to begyle. By √æat tyme √æe lord of the towne Hadde ordeynyd tymbyr redy bowne, An halle to make of tre. After the wryght the lord lett sende For √æat he schuld wyth hym lende Monythys two or thre. The lord seyd, ‚Äúwoult √æou haue √æi wyfe? I wylle send after her blyve That sche may com to the.‚Äù The wryght hys garlond hadde take wyth hym, That was bryght and no √æing dymme, Yt wes feyre on to see. The lord axyd hym as he satt, ‚ÄúFelowe, where hadyst √æou √æis hatte That ys so feyre and newe?‚Äù The wryght answerd alle so blyue, And seyd, ‚Äúsyr, I hadde yt wyth my wyfe, And √æat dare me neuere rewe; Syr, by my garlond I may see Fekylle or fals yf √æat sche be, Or yf √æat sche be trewe; And yf my wyfe loue a paramoure, Than wylle my garlond vade coloure, And change wylle yt the hewe.‚Äù The lord √æought ‚Äúby godys myght, That wylle I wete thys same nyght Whether thys tale be trewe.‚Äù To the wryghtys howse anon he went, He fonde the wyfe ther-in presente That was so bryght and schene; Sone he hayled her trewly, And so dyd sche the lord curtesly: Sche seyd, ‚Äúwelcome ye be;‚Äù Thus seyd the wyfe of the hows, ‚ÄúSyr, howe faryth my swete spowse That hewyth vppon youre tre?‚Äù ‚ÄúSertes, dame,‚Äù he seyd, ‚Äúwele, And I am come, so haue I hele, To wete the wylle of the; My loue ys so vppon the cast That me thynketh my hert wolle brest, It wolle none otherwyse be; Good dame, graunt me thy grace To pley with the in some preuy place For gold and eke for fee.‚Äù ‚ÄúGood syr, lett be youre fare, And of such wordes speke no mare For hys loue √æat dyed on tre; Hadde we onys begonne √æat gle, My husbond by his garlond myght see; For sorowe he would wexe woode.‚Äù ‚ÄúCertes, dame,‚Äù he seyd, ‚Äúnaye; Loue me, I pray you, in √æat ye maye: For godys loue change thy mode, Forty marke schalle be youre mede Of syluer and of gold [so] rede, And that schalle do the good.‚Äù ‚ÄúSyr, that deede schalle be done; Take me that mony here anone.‚Äù ‚ÄúI swere by the holy rode I thought when I cam hyddere For to bryng yt alle to-gyddere, As I mott breke my heele.‚Äù Ther sche toke xl marke Of syluer and gold styff and sterke: Sche toke yt feyre and welle; Sche seyd, ‚Äúin to the chambyr wylle we, Ther no man schalle vs see; No lenger wylle we spare.‚Äù Vp the steyer they gan hye: The stepes were made so queyntly That farther myght he nott fare. The lord stumbyllyd as he went in hast, He felle doune in to √æat chaste Forty fote and somedele more. The lord began to crye; The wyfe seyd to hym in hye, ‚ÄúSyr, what do ye there?‚Äù ‚ÄúDame, I can nott seye howe That I am come hydder nowe To thys hows √æat ys so newe; I am so depe in thys sure flore That I ne can come owte att no dore; Good dame, on me √æou rewe!‚Äù ‚ÄúNay,‚Äù sche seyd, ‚Äúso mut y the, Tylle myne husbond come and se, I schrewe hym √æat yt √æought.‚Äù The lord arose and lokyd abowte If he myght eny where gete owte, But yt holpe hym ryght noght, The wallys were so thycke wythyn, That he no where myght owte wynne But helpe to hym were brought; And euer the lord made euylle chere, And seyd, ‚Äúdame, √æou schalt by thys dere.‚Äù Sche seyd that sche ne rought; Sche seyd ‚ÄúI recke nere Whyle I am here and √æou art there, I schrewe herre √æat √æe doth drede.‚Äù The lord was sone owte of her √æought, The wyfe went in to her lofte, Sche satte and dyd here dede. Than yt felle on √æat o√æer daye Of mete and drynke he gan her pray, There of he hadde gret nede. He seyd, ‚Äúdame, for seynt charyte, Wyth some mete √æou comfort me.‚Äù Sche seyd, ‚Äúnay, so god me spede, For I swere by swete seynt Iohne, Mete ne drynke ne getyst √æou none Butt √æou wylt swete or swynke; For I haue both hempe and lyne, And a betyngstocke fulle fyne, And a swyngylle good and grete; If √æou wylt worke, tell me sone.‚Äù ‚ÄúDame, bryng yt forthe, yt schalle be done, Fulle gladly would I ete.‚Äù Sche toke the stocke in her honde, And in to the pytt sche yt sclang Wyth a grete hete: Sche brought the lyne and hempe on her backe, ‚ÄúSyr lord,‚Äù sche seyd, ‚Äúhaue √æou √æat, And lerne for to swete.‚Äù Ther sche toke hym a bonde For to occupy hys honde, And bade hym fast on to bete. He leyd yt downe on the stone, And leyd on strockes welle good wone, And sparyd nott on to leyne. Whan √æat he hadde wrought a thraue, Mete and drynke he gan to craue, And would haue hadde yt fayne; ‚ÄúThat I hadde somewhat for to ete Now after my gret swete; Me thynketh yt were ryght, For I haue labouryd nyght and daye The for to plese, dame, I saye, And therto putt my myght.‚Äù The wyfe seyd ‚Äúso mutt I haue hele, And yf √æi worke be wrought wele Thou schalt haue to dyne.‚Äù Mete and drynke sche hym bare, Wyth a thrafe of flex mare Of fulle long boundyn lyne. So feyre the wyfe the lord gan praye That he schuld be werkyng aye, And nought √æat he schuld blynne; The lord was fayne to werke tho, Butt hys men knewe nott of hys woo Nor of √æer lordes pyne. The stuard to √æe wryght gan saye, ‚ÄúSawe √æou owte of my lord to-daye, Whether that he ys wende?‚Äù The wryght answerde and seyd ‚Äúnaye; I sawe hym nott syth yesterdaye; I trowe √æat he be schent.‚Äù The stuard stode √æe wryght by, And of hys garlond hadde ferly What √æat yt be-mente. The stuard seyd, ‚Äúso god me saue, Of thy garlond wondyr I haue, And who yt hath the sent.‚Äù ‚ÄúSyr,‚Äù he seyd, ‚Äúbe the same hatte I can knowe yf my wyfe be badde To me by eny other man; If my floures ou√æer fade or falle, Then doth my wyfe me wrong wyth-alle, As many a woman can.‚Äù The stuard √æought ‚Äúby godes myght, That schalle I preue thys same nyght Whether √æou blys or banne,‚Äù And in to hys chambyr he gan gone, And toke tresure fulle good wone, And forth he spedde hem than. Butt he ne stynt att no stone Tylle he vn-to √æe wryghtes hows come That ylke same nyght. He mett the wyfe amydde the gate, Abowte √æe necke he gan her take, And seyd ‚Äúmy dere wyght, Alle the good √æat ys myne I wylle the geue to be thyne To lye by the alle nyght.‚Äù Sche seyd, ‚Äúsyr, lett be thy fare, My husbond wolle wete wyth-owtyn mare And I hym dyd that vnryght; I would nott he myght yt wete For alle the good that I myght gete, So Ihesus mutt me spede; For, and eny man lay me by, My husbond would yt wete truly, It ys wythowtyn eny drede.‚Äù The stuard seyd ‚Äúfor hym √æat ys wrought, There-of, dame, drede the noght Wyth me to do that dede; Haue here of me xx marke Of gold and syluer styf and starke, Thys tresoure schalle be thy mede.‚Äù ‚ÄúSyr, and I graunt √æat to you, Lett no man wete butt we two nowe.‚Äù He seyd, ‚Äúnay, wythowtyn drede.‚Äù The stuard √æought, ‚Äòsykerly Women beth both queynte & slye.‚Äô The mony he gan her bede; He √æought wele to haue be spedde, And of his erand he was onredde Or he were fro hem I-gone. Vp the sterys sche hym leyde Tylle he saw the wryghtes bedde: Of tresoure rought he none; He went and stumblyd att a stone, In to √æe sellere he fylle sone Downe to the bare flore. The lord seyd ‚Äúwhat deuylle art √æou? And √æou hadest falle on me nowe, Thowe hadest hurt me fulle sore.‚Äù The stuard stert and staryd abowte If he myght ower gete owte Att hole lesse or mare. The lord seyd, ‚Äúwelcome, and sytt be tyme, For √æou schalt helpe to dyght thys lyne For alle thy fers fare.‚Äù The stuard lokyd on the knyght, He seyd, ‚Äúsyr, for godes myght, My lord, what do you here?‚Äù He seyd ‚Äúfelowe, wyth-owtyn oth, For o erand we come bothe, The sothe wolle I nott lete.‚Äù Tho cam the wyfe them vn-to, And seyd, ‚Äúsyres, what do you to, Wylle ye nott lerne to swete?‚Äù Than seyd √æe lord her vn-to, ‚ÄúDame, youre lyne ys I-doo, Nowe would I fayne ete: And I haue made yt alle I-lyke, Fulle clere, and no √æing thycke, Me thynketh yt gret payne.‚Äù The stuard seyd ‚Äúwyth-owtyn dowte, And euer I may wynne owte, I wyll breke her brayne.‚Äù ‚ÄúFelowe, lett be, and sey nott so, For √æou schalt worke or euer √æou goo, Thy wordes √æou torne agayne, Fayne √æou schalt be so to doo, And thy good wylle put √æerto; As a man buxome and bayne Thowe schalt rubbe, rele, and spynne, And √æou wolt eny mete wynne, That I geue to god a gyfte.‚Äù The stuard seyd, ‚Äúthen haue I wondyr; Rather would I dy for hungyr Wyth-owte hosylle or shryfte.‚Äù The lord seyd, ‚Äúso haue I hele, Thowe wylt worke, yf √æou hungyr welle, What worke √æat the be brought.‚Äù The lord satt and dyd hys werke, The stuard drewe in to the derke, Gret sorowe was in hys √æought. The lord seyd, ‚Äúdame, here ys youre lyne, Haue yt in godes blessyng and myne, I hold yt welle I-wrought.‚Äù Mete and drynke sche gaue hym yn, ‚ÄúThe stuard,‚Äù sche seyd, ‚Äúwolle he nott spynne, Wylle he do ryght noght?‚Äù The lord seyd, ‚Äúby swete sen Ione, Of thys mete schalle he haue none That ye haue me hydder brought.‚Äù The lord ete and dranke fast, The stuard hungeryd att √æe last, For he gaue hym nought. The stuard satt alle in a stody, Hys lord hadde forgote curtesy: Tho seyd √æe stuard, ‚Äúgeue me some.‚Äù The lord seyd, ‚Äúsorow haue √æe morselle or sope That schalle come in thy throte; Nott so much as a crome! Butt √æou wylt helpe to dyght √æis lyne, Much hungyr yt schalle be thyne Though √æou make much mone.‚Äù Vp he rose, and went therto, ‚ÄúBetter ys me √æus to doo Whyle yt must nedys be do.‚Äù The stuard began fast to knocke, The wyfe √ærew hym a swyngelyng stocke, Hys mete √æerwyth to wyn; Sche brought a swyngylle at √æe last, ‚ÄúGood syres,‚Äù sche seyd, ‚Äúswyngylle on fast; For no √æing that ye blynne.‚Äù Sche gaue hym a stocke to sytt vppon, And seyd ‚Äúsyres, √æis werke must nedys be done, Alle that that ys here yn.‚Äù The stuard toke vp a stycke to saye, ‚ÄúSey, seye, swyngylle better yf ye may, Hytt wylle be the better to spynne.‚Äù Were √æe lord neuer so gret, Yet was he fayne to werke for hys mete Though he were neuer so sadde; Butt √æe stuard √æat was so stowde, Was fayne to swyngelle √æe scales owte, Ther-of he was nott glad. The lordys meyne √æat were att home Wyst nott where he was bycome, They were fulle sore adrad. The proctoure of √æe parysche chyrche ryght Came and lokyd on √æe wryght, He lokyd as he were madde; Fast √æe proctoure gan hym frayne, ‚ÄúWhere hadest √æou √æis garlond gayne? It ys euer lyke newe.‚Äù The wryght gan say ‚Äúfelowe, Wyth my wyfe, yf √æou wylt knowe; That dare me nott rewe; For alle the whyle my wyfe trew ys, My garlond wolle hold hewe I-wys, And neuer falle nor fade; And yf my wyfe take a paramoure, Than wolle my garlond vade √æe floure, That dare I ley myne hede.‚Äù The proctoure √æought, ‚Äúin good faye That schalle I wete thys same daye Whether yt may so be.‚Äù To the wryghtes hows he went, He grete √æe wyfe wyth feyre entente, Sche seyd ‚Äúsyr, welcome be ye.‚Äù ‚ÄúA! dame, my loue ys on you fast Syth the tyme I sawe you last; I pray you yt may so be That ye would graunt me of youre grace To play wyth you in some priuy place, Or ellys to deth mutt me.‚Äù Fast √æe proctoure gan to pray, And euer to hym sche seyd ‚Äúnaye, That wolle I nott doo. Hadest √æou done √æat dede wyth me, My spouse by hys garlond myght see, That schuld torne me to woe.‚Äù The proctoure seyd, ‚Äúby heuen kyng, If he sey to the any √æing He schalle haue sorowe vnsowte; Twenty marke I wolle √æe geue, It wolle √æe helpe welle to lyue, The mony here haue I brought.‚Äù Nowe hath sche the tresure tane, And vp √æe steyre be they gane, (What helpyth yt to lye?) The wyfe went the steyre be-syde, The proctoure went a lytylle to wyde He felle downe by and by. Whan he in to √æe seller felle, He wente to haue sonke in to helle, He was in hart fulle sory. The stuard lokyd on the knyght, And seyd ‚Äúproctoure, for godes myght, Come and sytt vs by.‚Äù The proctoure began to stare, For he was he wyst neuer whare, Butt wele he knewe √æe knyght And the stuard √æat swyngelyd √æe lyne. He seyd ‚Äúsyres, for godes pyne, What do ye here thys nyght?‚Äù The stuard seyd, ‚Äúgod geue the care, Thowe camyst to loke howe we fare, Nowe helpe √æis lyne were dyght.‚Äù He stode stylle in a gret √æought, What to answer he wyst noght: ‚ÄúBy mary fulle of myght,‚Äù The proctoure seyd, ‚Äúwhat do ye in √æis yn For to bete thys wyfes lyne? For Jhesus loue, fulle of myght,‚Äù The proctoure seyd ryght as he √æought, ‚ÄúFor me yt schalle be euylle wrought And I may see aryght, For I lernyd neuer in londe For to haue a swyngelle in hond By day nor be nyght.‚Äù The stuard seyd, ‚Äúas good as √æou We hold vs that be here now, And lett preue yt be syght; Yet must vs worke for owre mete, Or ellys schalle we none gete, Mete nor drynke to owre honde.‚Äù The lord seyd, ‚Äúwhy flyte ye two? I trowe ye wylle werke or ye goo Yf yt be as I vndyrstond.‚Äù Abowte he goys twyes or thryes; They ete & drynke in such wyse That √æey geue hym ryght noght. The proctoure seyd, ‚Äúthynke ye no schame, Yheue me some mete, (ye be to blame,) Of that the wyfe ye brought.‚Äù The stuard seyd ‚Äúeuylle spede the soppe If eny morcelle come in thy throte Butt √æou wyth vs hadest wrought.‚Äù The proctoure stode in a stody Whether he myght worke hem by; And so to torne hys √æought, To the lord he drewe nere, And to hym seyd wyth myld chere, ‚ÄúThat mary mott the spede.‚Äù The proctoure began to knocke, The good wyfe rawte hym a rocke, For therto hadde sche nede; Sche seyd ‚Äúwhan I was mayde att home, Other werke cowde I do none My lyfe ther-wyth to lede.‚Äù Sche gaue hym in hande a rocke hynde, And bade hem fast for to wynde Or ellys to lett be hys dede. ‚ÄúYes, dame,‚Äù he seyd, ‚Äúso haue I hele, I schalle yt worke both feyre & welle As ye haue taute me.‚Äù He wauyd vp a strycke of lyne, And he span wele and fyne By-fore the swyngelle tre. The lord seyd ‚Äú√æou spynnest to grete, Therfor √æou schalt haue no mete, That √æou schalt welle see.‚Äù Thus √æey satt and wrought fast Tylle √æe weke dayes were past; Then the wryght, home came he, And as he cam by hys hows syde He herd noyse that was not ryde Of persons two or thre; One of hem knockyd lyne, A-nothyr swyngelyd good and fyne By-fore the swyngylle tre, The thyrde did rele and spynne, Mete and drynke ther-wyth to wynne, Gret nede ther-of hadde he. Thus √æe wryght stode herkenyng; Hys wyfe was ware of hys comyng, And ageynst hym went sche. ‚ÄúDame,‚Äù he seyd, ‚Äúwhat ys √æis dynne?
